paragraphs.content: We saw in Unit 7 that a direct object is the person or thing that the verb directly impacts on. An indirect object is the person or thing that the action is happening to or for: Scrivo a Carla domani (I’ll write to Carla tomorrow); Mando cartoline a tutti i miei amici (I send cards to all my friends). In English, the indirect object can usually be preceded by ‘to’ or ‘for’, but these are very often omitted: compare ‘I gave the book to Karen’ and ‘I gave Karen the book’, or ‘I’ll pour a glass for Jane’ and ‘I’ll pour Jane a glass’.

An indirect object pronoun replaces a noun used as an indirect object: ‘I gave the book to her/I gave her the book’, ‘I’ll pour her a glass/I’ll pour a glass for her’. In Italian, an indirect object pronoun replaces a noun preceded by the preposition a; it has to agree in gender and number with the noun it refers to. Indirect object pronouns normally come before the verb. In the following examples, the pronouns are in italics:

rows: Quando vedo *Maria* *le* racconto tutto. [le stands for a Maria (fs)]
When I see Maria I’ll tell *her* everything.
Non telefono *a Carlo*, *gli* scrivo. [gli stands for a Carlo (ms)]
I’m not going to phone Carlo: I’ll write to *him*.
Paolo non *ci* dice mai la verità. [ci stands for a noi]

paragraphs.content: The forms of the indirect object pronouns are as follows:

The third person plural pronoun gli is used for both masculine and feminine. For the third person plural, loro can be used instead of gli, but it always follows the verb; the meaning is the same, but the use of loro is far less frequent and is more formal.

rows: Will you send *me* a postcard from Rome?
I’ll write to *you* as soon as I arrive.
È il compleanno di Anna: *le* regalo un CD.
It’s Anna’s birthday: I’m giving *her* a CD.
Se Dario non ha l’auto, *gli* do un passaggio.
If Dario hasn’t got his car, I’ll give *him* a lift.
‘Are you going to write to your uncles?’ ‘No, I’ll phone *them* tomorrow.’
I’m going to tell *them* the truth.

paragraphs.content: The negative is formed by putting **non** before the pronoun:

rows: I’m not going to write (to *her*), I’ll phone *her*.
I’m not going to reply to/answer *him*.

paragraphs.content: When an indirect object pronoun is used with a verb in the infinitive (usually after verbs like dovere, potere, volere or sapere), it can be attached to the infinitive, which drops the final vowel:
Each pair of sentences has exactly the same meaning – the form used makes no difference.

rows: *Mi* sai dire quando? or Sai *dirmi* quando?

paragraphs.content: The indirect object pronouns used for the formal form are Le for the singular (for both women and men) and Vi for the plural (the pronoun Loro – after the verb – can also be used, but this is very formal):

rows: Professor Masi, I’ll write to *you* tomorrow.
Mr. and Mrs. Bianchi, I’ll send *you* the documents.
Mr. and Mrs. Bianchi, I’ll send *you* the documents.

exercises.title: Exercise 1: Indirect Object Pronouns
exercises.instruction: Rewrite the sentences, replacing the words in italics with the correct indirect object pronoun.
examples: Spedisco le cartoline *ai miei amici*: *Gli* spedisco le cartoline.

items.question: La nonna legge un libro *ai nipoti*.
items.answer: La nonna gli legge un libro.

items.answer: Gli amici non le offrono un gelato.

items.question: Paolo *mi* dice la verità.
items.answer: Paolo non mi dice la verità.

exercises.instruction: Complete the sentences with the correct indirect object pronoun.
examples: Mauro ha molti amici e —— telefona spesso: gli

items.question: ‘Cosa regali a tuo padre?’ ‘____ regalo una cravatta.’
Se vedi le mie amiche, puoi dir ____ che le aspetto per domani?
‘Ci portate un regalo, dall’Italia?’ ‘Sì, ____ portiamo un panettone.’
‘Cosa vuoi dir____?’ ‘Vi voglio dire la verità.’
‘Quando telefoni ai nonni?’ ‘____ telefono domani sera.’
Non so fare questo esercizio: ____ dai una mano?
Domani è il compleanno di Anna: devo far____ gli auguri.
Paolo dice sempre bugie: non ____ dovete credere.
Telefono a Michele e ____ chiedo un prestito.
Se non avete l’auto, ____ dò un passaggio.
Se Carla e Pietro hanno bisogno di soldi, ____ posso fare un prestito.
Appena vedo Silvia ____ rendo i libri.
Se vuoi, ____ impresto la mia bici.
Ettore è un buon amico e ____ racconto sempre tutto.

exercises.title: Exercise 5: Translate into Italian
exercises.instruction: Translate the following sentences into Italian.
examples: Can you [sing.] tell *Lucia* that I want to speak to *her*?: Puoi dire *a Lucia* che voglio *parlarle*?
As soon as I arrive in Rome I’ll phone *you [pl.]*: Appena arrivo a Roma *vi* telefono.

items.question: Can you [sing.] tell *Lucia* that I want to speak to *her*?
answer: Puoi dire a Lucia che le voglio parlare?
Puoi dire a Lucia che voglio parlarle?

items.question: As soon as I arrive in Rome I’ll phone *you [pl.]*.
items.answer: Appena arrivo a Roma vi telefono.

items.question: I have to ask *you* a favour, Madam.
answer: Devo  chiederle  chiedere un favore, Signora.
Devo  Le  devo  chiedere un favore, Signora.

items.question: Are *you [sing.]* giving *them* your phone number?
items.answer: Gli dai il tuo numero di telefono?

items.question: They always tell *us* interesting things.
answer: Ci dicono sempre delle cose interessanti.

items.question: They always send *me* a card when they go to Italy.
items.answer: Mi mandano sempre una cartolina quando vanno in Italia.

items.question: For *her* birthday, I’m giving *her* flowers.
items.answer: Per il suo compleanno, le regalo dei fiori.

items.question: I’ve got to give *you [sing.]* *Luca’s* books.
answer: Devo darti i libri di Luca.
Ti devo dare i libri di Luca.

items.question: If *you [pl.]* want, I’ll tell *you* a story.
items.answer: Se volete, vi racconto una storia.

items.question: Massimo writes to *me* every week.
answer: Massimo mi scrive tutte le settimane.
